clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Study of the Effect of Yoga in Patients With Breast Cancer Receiving Radiation Therapy

lead_sponsor.agency: Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania

clinical_study.source: Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to examine the use of Eischens yoga for 8 weeks in one cohort of 20 women with stage I and II breast cancer receiving radiation therapy treatment, while a second cohort of the same type of and number of patients who, instead of yoga will receive standard supportive therapy, Questionnaire measuring cancer-related quality of life (FACT-G instrument) and fatigue (Brief Fatique Inventory) will be given to patients at several points.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Primary Purpose: Supportive Care
clinical_study.condition: Women With Stage I or II Breast Cancer Undergoing Active Radiation Therapy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Stage I and II breast cancer patients undergoing active radiation therapy
- Above the age of 18
- Must sign informed consent form
- Must speak English
- Only women are eligible
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with medical restrictions that may interfere with yoga participation per their physicians' decision
- Those who have smoked in the last 6 months because smoking can interfere with the breathing and relaxation techniques of yoga.
- Those who have regularly taken yoga in the last 6 months, because they would not come to the intervention with the same baseline as other participants.
